questions.question: The intense pain associated with a distal pulp space infection (felon) occurs because:
options: It is a closed space infection
questions.explanation: A felon infects the closed fibrous septal compartments of the pulp. Pus accumulation in this non-compliant space raises pressure rapidly (compartment syndrome), causing intense throbbing pain.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the following are surgical risk in a diabetic patient except:
questions.explanation: While neuropathy affects pain perception, 'pain control' is not a direct physiological surgical complication like the others.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: HAI; which of the following is the most commonly acquired infection in hospitalized surgical patients?
questions.explanation: In surgical patients specifically, Surgical Site Infections (SSIs) are often the commonest type of nosocomial infection, followed closely by UTI, respiratory infections.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following factors influences healing of a wound?
questions.explanation: While all influence healing, the wound site is a fundamental local factor (e.g., face vs. foot) due to differences in vascularity, often highlighted as a primary determinant.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Dobutamine is one of drugs can be used in treatment of shock; its action is:
options: Decreases cardiac output and causes peripheral vasodilation
Decreases cardiac output and causes peripheral vasoconstriction
Increases cardiac output and causes peripheral vasoconstriction
Increases cardiac output and causes peripheral vasodilation
questions.explanation: Dobutamine is a beta-1 agonist that increases myocardial contractility and cardiac output. It also has mild beta-2 activity, causing peripheral vasodilation and reduced afterload.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 7-year-old female has a painless midline neck lump moving with swallowing and tongue protrusion. History includes recurrent inflammation responding to antibiotics. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Movement with tongue protrusion is the pathognomonic sign of a Thyroglossal Duct Cyst, as the tract is connected to the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Bradykinin, serotonin and histamine among mediators released in response to wounds; they are released from:
questions.explanation: Mast cells degranulate immediately upon injury, releasing histamine and serotonin (and other vasoactive amines), initiating the inflammatory response.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 40-years old male patient presented with strangulated hernia; the hernia clinically is:
options: Tender with intact impulse on cough.
questions.explanation: Strangulation implies compromised blood supply. The hernia becomes tense, tender, irreducible, and loses the cough impulse due to complete blockage at the neck.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 65 years old male presented with claudication pain; which been of the following drugs have been shown to improve claudication?
questions.explanation: Oxpentifylline (Pentoxifylline) and Cilostazol are rheologic agents approved to improve walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication by improving blood flow properties.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A child 10-years old presented with manifestations of testicular torsion; regarding this condition:
options: CT scan should be done to confim the diagnosis
It is most common above 25 years of age.
Inversion of the testis and a transverse lie are not a cause.
The typical symptom is a scrotal swelling
The emergency operation should be done, and fixation of testis on other side must be done.
questions.explanation: Torsion is an emergency. If confirmed, the testis is untwisted or removed. Contralateral orchiopexy is mandatory because the anatomical defect (bell-clapper deformity) is usually bilateral.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A patient presented to emergency department with disturbed conscious level, temperature 39.5, B.P. 80/45, chest x-ray shows ground glass appearance of both lung fields. This patient has:
questions.explanation: The combination of high fever (39.5Â°C), hypotension, and lung findings consistent with ARDS (ground glass) strongly suggests Septic Shock.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About the rule of nines for burns classification:
questions.explanation: In the Wallace Rule of Nines for adults: Each lower limb is 18%, each upper limb is 9%, the head/neck is 9%, anterior trunk is 18%, posterior trunk is 18%, and perineum is 1%.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the followings are presentations of cancer tongue except:
questions.explanation: Tongue cancer presents with ulcers, fissures, halitosis, or referred otalgia. Maxillary swelling is associated with maxillary tumors, not tongue lesions.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regards the pathogenesis and treatment of abscess:
options: Antibiotics are indicated if there is evidence of pus formation.
Most wound-site abscesses occur before the patient is discharged from the hospital.
Staphylococcus aurous is one of the most common causative organisms.
Pus formation occur at the seventh day of infection
The abscess wall is composed of epithelium.
questions.explanation: S. aureus is a common cause. Antibiotics alone are insufficient if pus exists (drainage needed). The wall is granulation tissue (pyogenic membrane), not epithelium.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Benign breast diseases are common conditions; all of the following concepts are true as regard, except:
options: Fibroadenoma is the commonest benign tumor.
Fibrocystic disease is the commonest benign disease
Lipoma is a common condition of the breast.
Traumatic fat necrosis can be mistaken for a carcinoma.
30 percent of breast cysts recur after aspiration.
questions.explanation: Lipomas are neoplasms of subcutaneous tissue, not breast parenchyma. In the context of specific breast pathology, they are less clinically significant than fibroadenomas or cysts.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning carcinoma of the lip; the following statements are true except:
options: Affects males much more often than females.
Commonly a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.
May produce a Kissing cancer on the other lip,
Occurs mostly in the middle of lower lip.
Spreads to the regional glands by lymphatic permeation.
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lip spreads to lymph nodes primarily by lymphatic embolization, not permeation. Permeation is a continuous growth along lymphatics, which is rare and a late feature.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning inhalation injury of burn; which of the following statements are true?
options: Distal airway injuries are usually caused by heat injury
Endotracheal intubation is indicated immediately in all patients with suspected inhalation injury
It is due to upper airway obstruction secondary to progressive edema and reactive bronchospasm
Oxygenation increase the extent of injury
Peak inspiratory pressures of> 40 cm of water are indicated to maintain functional residual capacity
questions.explanation: Inhalation injury causes upper airway edema. Immediate intubation is indicated for impending obstruction due to progressive edema and potential airway loss.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: During coagulation process; which of the following clotting factors is consumed?
questions.explanation: Fibrinogen (Factor I) is converted into fibrin to form the clot and is therefore consumed during coagulation (absent in serum).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding amputation, all of the following are an indication for major amputation except:
options: Clostridium infection of the lower leg.
questions.explanation: Neurofibromas are benign tumors treated with local excision. They are not an indication for major amputation unless rare malignant transformation or massive deformity occurs.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding epigastric hernia; which of the following statements is correct about the diagnosis and management?
options: A large peritoneal sac containing abdominal viscera is common
At the time of surgical repair, a careful search for other defects should be performed
Painful midline masses frequently contain incarcerated small bowel
Recurrent epigastric hernias after simple closure is uncommon
questions.explanation: Epigastric hernias occur through defects in the linea alba and are often multiple (fenestrations). Therefore, checking for other adjacent defects during repair is standard practice.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding varicose veins of the lower limb; which of the following are true?
options: Handheld Doppler provides an accurate assessment of sapheno-popliteal competence.
Right leg varicose veins are more common than left leg varicose veins.
The prevalence of varicose veins is twice more common in women than in men
Varicose veins may cause venous claudication.
Varicose veins may be associated with the fOXC2 gene.
questions.explanation: Mutations in the FOXC2 gene have been associated with lymphedema-distichiasis syndrome and varicose veins, highlighting a genetic component to valve failure/vein wall weakness.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Salivary gland carcinoma with perineural spread to the brain is:
questions.explanation: Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma is notorious for its tendency for perineural invasion, allowing it to spread along nerves (e.g., Facial nerve) intracranially.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site for a parotid tumor is:
options: At the anterior border of the masseter
Behind the angle of the mandible
Inferior to the angle of the mandible.
questions.explanation: Parotid tumors frequently arise in the tail of the gland, located behind/inferior to the angle of the mandible, or in the superficial lobe anterior to the ear.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site of the following diseases is correctly matched:
options: Basal cell carcinoma: arm and hand
Keloids: face, neck, and skin over sternum
questions.explanation: Keloids are most common in areas of high skin tension and specific predilection sites like the presternal area, shoulders, earlobes, and face/neck.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: There are many causes that impair wound healing; the major cause is:
questions.explanation: Local tissue infection is a leading and major cause of delayed wound healing as bacteria prolong the inflammatory phase and release toxins that destroy tissue.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An 18-year-old female presents with a well circumscribed 2-cm mass in her right breast. The mass is painless and has a rubbery consistency and discrete borders. It appears to move freely through the breast tissue. What is the likeliest diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A painless, rubbery, well-circumscribed, and highly mobile mass ('breast mouse') in a young woman is the classic presentation of a Fibroadenoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common presentation of Hodgkin lymphoma is:
questions.explanation: The hallmark presentation of Hodgkin lymphoma is painless enlargement of lymph nodes, most commonly in the cervical region.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding lymphedema; all of the following are a risk factor except:
questions.explanation: A Baker's cyst is synovial fluid in the popliteal fossa mimicking DVT. It is not a direct cause or risk factor for chronic lymphedema.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is a symptom of hemolytic transfusion reaction?
questions.explanation: Symptoms of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction include fever, chills, flank/loin pain, and constricting chest pain/tightness due to the systemic inflammatory response and potential shock.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning umbilical hernias in adult; the following statement is true:
options: A paraumbilical hernia typically occurs in multiparous females
Incarceration is uncommon with umbilical hernias
Most umbilical hernias in adults are the result of a congenital defect carried into adulthood
The presence of ascites is a contraindication to umbilical hernia repair
The treatment of choice is herniorrhaphy
questions.explanation: Adult 'umbilical' hernias are usually acquired paraumbilical hernias, seen in multiparous or obese patients due to linea alba stretching and raised abdominal pressure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The first evidence of a rectus sheath hematoma is:
options: Development of an abdominal wall mass
questions.explanation: Rectus sheath hematoma often presents with sudden, sharp abdominal pain, typically following coughing or straining which tears the epigastric vessels.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding causes of A-V fistula, the following statement is false:
options: Rupture of arterial aneurysm into an adjacent vein
questions.explanation: Vasculitis causes stenosis, thrombosis, or aneurysms. It is not a standard cause of Arteriovenous Fistula (AVF) formation, unlike trauma or congenital defects.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sebaceous cyst is characterized by the following: it
options: Is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.
Is always anchored to the overlying skin at multiple areas
May occur on the palms and soles
questions.explanation: A 'sebaceous cyst' (epidermoid cyst) is lined by stratified squamous epithelium and contains keratin. It attaches to the skin at a single point (punctum), not multiple.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 55-years old male presented with acute ischaemia of the lower limb; pain is more prominent at the:
options: Most proximal part of the limb
Most peripheral part of the limb
questions.explanation: In acute ischemia, pain is most severe in the most distal (peripheral) part of the limb (toes/foot) due to the complete lack of blood supply distally.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common indication of surgical correction of varicocele is:
questions.explanation: Varicoceles are a common treatable cause of male infertility. Subfertility (with abnormal semen analysis) is the most common indication for surgical ligation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Patient presented by open wound at foot, about wound healing:
options: Irradiation is associated with rapid wound healing
Infected wounds heal by primary intention
questions.explanation: Adequate blood supply is crucial for wound healing (oxygen/nutrients). Ischemia significantly impairs and delays the healing process.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regards enteral nutrition, it:
options: Has a higher complication rate than parental nutrition
Is a nutritional support taken only through a nasogastric tube
Is more expensive than parental nutrition
Result in a reduction of infections complications in critically ill patients
Result in faster return of bowel function in healthy patients after gastrointestinal
questions.explanation: Enteral nutrition maintains the gut mucosal barrier (preventing translocation), supports GALT, and has fewer infectious complications than TPN.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Congenital dermoid cysts are characterized by the following feature:
options: May cause hollowing of subjacent bone
Often attached to the overlying skin
questions.explanation: Congenital dermoid cysts (e.g., external angular dermoid) are deep to the skin and can cause pressure excavation (hollowing) of the underlying bone.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hemangioma of the face in children:
options: Can be treated by laser ablation
Cirsoid aneurism is one of its types
Should be resected in the newborn period
Should be resected only if it persists 10 years of age
Will involute by 3 years of age in most children
questions.explanation: While most involute, laser ablation (Pulsed Dye Laser) is valid for superficial components or complications (ulceration) and is standard for Port Wine Stains.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common nosocomial infections involve the following:
questions.explanation: Overall, urinary tract infections (Catheter-Associated UTI) are the most common type of hospital-acquired (nosocomial) infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Septic shock is a type of shock that commonly observed in surgical field; signs associated with early sepsis include:
questions.explanation: Early septic shock is characterized by a hyperdynamic state ('Warm Shock') with cutaneous vasodilation, warm skin, and increased cardiac output.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Steroid is a factor that impairs wound healing; this impairment occurs due to:
questions.explanation: Corticosteroids inhibit the inflammatory phase of wound healing by decreasing macrophage migration and reducing angiogenesis and collagen synthesis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common fluid or electrolyte disorder in the surgical patient is:
questions.explanation: ECF volume deficit (hypovolemia/dehydration) is the most common fluid disorder in surgical patients due to fluid loss (bleeding, vomiting, third spacing, NPO status).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment of choice for cystic hygromas is:
questions.explanation: While sclerotherapy is increasingly used, surgical excision has traditionally been considered the definitive treatment for cystic hygroma (lymphangioma) to ensure complete removal.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Wound management one of the main topics in surgery; which of the following statement is true concerning the clinical management of an open wound?
options: A wet-to-dry dressing is the most optimal form of wound management
A moist occlusive dressing promotes epithelialization and reduces pain
Irrigation of the wound disrupts epithelialization therefore inhibiting the healing process
Povidine iodine is the best antiseptic solution
The protein rich plasma exudate covering the open wound facilitates healing
questions.explanation: Moist wound healing is the gold standard. Occlusive dressings maintain moisture, which accelerates epithelialization, prevents desiccation, and reduces pain.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The first lymph node station draining testis is:
questions.explanation: Testes develop retroperitoneally. Lymphatic drainage follows the blood supply to para-aortic (lumbar) nodes, not inguinal nodes (unless scrotal skin is involved).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Severe hemorrhage is a medical catastrophe; what percentage of blood volume must be lost in healthy patients before hypotension occurs?
questions.explanation: Hypotension typically develops in Class III hemorrhage, which corresponds to a blood loss of 30-40% (approx 1500-2000 ml). Class I and II are usually compensated with normal BP.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Desmoid tumors:
options: Arise from the periosteum of the rib
Are treated with wide local excision with a 2- to 4- cm margin
Require chemotherapy to treat or prevent metastatic disease
Require radical excision (sacrificing neurovascular structures) to obtain 4-cm margins
questions.explanation: Desmoid tumors are locally aggressive fibroblasts but do not metastasize. The treatment of choice is wide local excision with clear margins to prevent high recurrence rates.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest cause of secondary hemorrhage is:
questions.explanation: Secondary hemorrhage occurs 7-14 days post-op and is almost invariably caused by infection eroding a vessel wall.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 39 years old carpenter presented by a swelling in the right groin, on examination; the swelling is reducible at lying flat and descend to the bottom of the scrotum in erect position, internal ring test is positive. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Hernias descending into the scrotum are typically Indirect. A 'positive' internal ring test (meaning occlusion of the ring controls/stops the hernia) confirms it is an Indirect Inguinal Hernia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 35-year old woman undergoes her first screening mammogram. Which of the following mammographic findings would require a breast biopsy?
options: A density that effaces with compression
Breast calcifications larger than 2 mm in diameter
Five or more clustered breast micro-calcifications per square centimeter
questions.explanation: Clustered microcalcifications (pleomorphic) are a suspicious finding on mammography, potentially indicating Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) or malignancy, and require biopsy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 65-year old patient presents with a painless, ulcerated lesion on his right check. The lesion has been present for 1 year. Physical examination of the patient's neck reveals no lymph node enlargement. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) typically presents as a painless, slow-growing ulcerated lesion (rodent ulcer) on sun-exposed areas like the cheek. It rarely metastasizes to lymph nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Acute arterial occlusion is caused by:
options: External compression by a growing tissue.
questions.explanation: Embolism (e.g., from AFib) causes sudden acute occlusion. Thrombosis on atherosclerosis is another cause, but emboli are distinctively acute without collaterals.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regards the pathogenesis and diagnosis of cellulitis:
options: This is a suppurative infection of tissues.
questions.explanation: Cellulitis is spreading subcutaneous inflammation. Unlike abscesses, it is poorly localized with indistinct borders, typically non-suppurative, and caused by Strep or Staph.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regards types of wounds: which of the following cases is considered clean contaminated wound?
options: Gunshot wound to the abdomen with injuries to small bowel and sigmoid colon
questions.explanation: A clean-contaminated wound involves controlled entry into a hollow viscus (respiratory, GI, GU tracts) without significant spillage or infection. Elective open cholecystectomy fits this definition.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Child 12 years old presented with manifestations of testicular torsion; regarding this condition;
options: CT scan should be done to confirm the diagnosis
It is most common above 25 years of age.
Inversion of the testis and a transverse lie are not a cause.
The typical symptom is a scrotal swelling
The emergency operation should be done, and fixation of testis on other side must be done.
questions.explanation: Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical exploration and detorsion. Because the anatomical defect (bell clapper) is bilateral, prophylactic fixation of the contralateral testis is mandatory.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Keloid is over scarring of wounds; it is characterized by the following:
options: Are particularly common in Negroes and pregnant females.
Develop after burns and vaccination marks only.
Occur most often on the abdomen, arm and front of the chest.
questions.explanation: Keloids have a strong genetic and racial predisposition, being much more common in dark-skinned individuals (African descent). Pregnancy can also exacerbate them.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Patient presented by manifestations of septic shock; he is responds best to:
questions.explanation: While fluids/antibiotics are crucial, 'Source Control' is definitive. Drainage of the septic collection (abscess, perforation) effectively stops the septic cascade.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding carpal tunnel syndrome:
options: It is rarely secondary to trauma
It may be associated with pregnancy
It most often causes dysesthesia during waking hours.
It is often associated with vascular compromise
Surgical treatment involves release of the extensor retinaculum
questions.explanation: Carpal tunnel syndrome is often associated with conditions causing fluid retention or connective tissue changes, such as pregnancy, hypothyroidism, and rheumatoid arthritis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the testicular neoplasms:
options: Mostly occurs above 60 years of age.
Lymphatic spread to inguinal lymph nodes.
Severe dull aching pain is a common presentation
questions.explanation: The vast majority (95%) of testicular masses are malignant germ cell tumors. They typically occur in young men (20-40) and spread to para-aortic nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The cause of lost expansile impulses on cough during hernia examination is:
questions.explanation: In strangulated hernia, tight neck constriction cuts blood supply and occludes the sac, preventing transmission of intra-abdominal pressure (cough impulse).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The type of hand infection which carries the highest risk of developing osteomyelitis is:
questions.explanation: A felon occurs in the tight pulp space adjacent to the distal phalanx. The pressure can compromise the blood supply to the bone or infection can spread directly, leading to osteomyelitis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is the percentage of burn does a patient who suffered to one leg (circumferential), one arm (circumferential) and the anterior trunk?
questions.explanation: Using the Rule of Nines: One leg = 18%. One arm = 9%. Anterior trunk = 18%. Total = 18 + 9 + 18 = 45%.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Claudication pain is one of the symptoms of ischemia:
options: Claudication distance is usually inconsistent on a day-to-day basis for a given patient.
Commonly relieved by getting out of bed.
Most commonly felt in the calf.
Thought to be due to nerve compression in the leg muscle compartments
questions.explanation: Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery (supplying the calf) is the most common site of atherosclerotic occlusion.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding direct inguinal hernias, they:
options: Are most common inguinal hernias in women
Commonly protrude into the scrotal sac in men
Incarcerate more commonly than indirect hernias
Protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels
Should be opened and ligated at the internal ring
questions.explanation: Direct inguinal hernias protrude through Hesselbach's triangle, which is located medial to the inferior epigastric vessels (unlike indirect hernias, which are lateral).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding third degree burn:
options: No graft is needed as a line of treatment
It is a partial thickness burn
questions.explanation: Third-degree (full-thickness) burns destroy all skin layers and nerve endings. They appear dry, leathery, white, or black (eschar) and are insensate (painless).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the lip:
options: Initially metastases are to the ipsilateral posterior cervical lymph nodes
More than 90 % of cases occur on the upper lip
Radiography is considered inappropriate treatment for these lesions
The lesion constitutes 30% of all cancers of oral cavity
The lesion often arises in areas of persistent hyperkeratosis.
questions.explanation: Lip carcinoma often arises from precursor lesions like actinic cheilitis or areas of chronic irritation/hyperkeratosis (leukoplakia).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis is commonly affects:
questions.explanation: TB lymphadenitis (Scrofula) most commonly affects the upper deep cervical lymph nodes (jugulodigastric group).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The earliest finding in tetanus infection is:
questions.explanation: While trismus is the classic sign, prodromal symptoms like dysphagia, restlessness, or neck stiffness can be the earliest findings before full trismus.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In a traumatized patient showing signs of bone fracture and acute ischemic, the patient should undergo:
options: Urgent ligation of the affected vessels
Urgent repair of the affected vessel
Reduction of the fracture and waiting for return of pulse is the first step
questions.explanation: Bone displacement may kink the vessel. Fracture reduction is the first step; if the pulse doesn't return immediately, vascular exploration is indicated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 68-year-old woman had a leg amputation for crush injury. Day 3 post-op, she is toxic with fever and tachycardia. The site is red, brawny, swollen, and has crepitus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of severe toxicity, brawny edema, and specifically 'crepitus' (gas) in the tissues following a crush injury amputation is diagnostic of Gas Gangrene (Clostridial myonecrosis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Post-operative infection, which of the following is the most effective way to prevent post-operative seroma/infection in an obese patient?
options: Closing the wound with a rubber drain
Closing the wound with a closed suction drain
Closing the wound with multiple sutures in the subcutaneous tissue
Leaving the subcutaneous tissue and skin open to heal by secondary intention
questions.explanation: In obese patients with large dead space, a closed suction drain is effective in removing fluid (seroma) and preventing accumulation that could become infected.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Wounds are healed by scar formation; concerning excessive scarring processes:
options: Hypertrophic scars and keloid are histologically different
Keloids tend to develop early and hypertrophic scars late after the surgical
Keloids occur randomly regardless of gender or race
Re-excision and closure of hypertrophic scars is useful if originally closed by secondary intention
questions.explanation: Unlike keloids, hypertrophic scars improve with time or excision/closure (reducing tension), especially if originally due to poor approximation or secondary intention.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Warthins tumor of salivary glands refers to;
questions.explanation: Warthin's tumor is also known as Adenolymphoma (Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum). It is a benign tumor, common in elderly males/smokers, occurring almost exclusively in the parotid.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Salivary gland stone is mostly occurring in
questions.explanation: Sialolithiasis most commonly affects the Submandibular gland (80%) because its saliva is more viscous, alkaline, and calcium-rich, and the duct drains against gravity.
questions.subject: General Surgery
